publicationStmt.publisher: Bib name / number: STC (2nd ed.) / 17479 Bib name / number: Greg, I, 203(a). / Physical description: [62] p. Copy from: Folger Shakespeare Library The malcontent. By Iohn Marston. 1604, At London : Printed by V[alentine] S[immes] for William Aspley, and are to be sold at his shop in Paules Church-yard, [1604]

sourceDesc.p: STC 17479, Queen's Revels edition, proofed by BDH

Play details
The malcontent. Genre: Tragi-comedy. Date first published: 1604. Date first performed: 1602-1604.

CountEquato Guerrino Maria CountCelso Mendoza Aurelia Maquerelle Passarello Beancha/Bianca Prologue/Epilogue Emillia Ferneze/Farneze all/omnes Captaine Author Page Mercurie

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

body.stage: The vilest out of tune Musicke being heard.

sp.speaker: Bilioso
sp.l: Why how now? are ye mad? or drunk? or both? or what?

sp.speaker: Pr:
sp.l: Are ye building Babilon there

sp.speaker: Bili:
sp.l: Here is a noise in Court, you think you are in a Tavern, do you not?

sp.speaker: Pr:
sp.p: You think you are in a brothel house, do you not? This room is ill scented.
So, perfume; perfume; some upon me I pray thee: The Duke is upon instant entrance; so, make place there.

body.stage: Enter the Duke Pietro, Ferrardo Count Equato Count Celso before, and Guerrino

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.l: Where breathes that music?

sp.speaker: Bilio:
sp.p: The discord rather than the Music is heard from the Malcontent Maleuoles chamber.

sp.speaker: Ferrar:
sp.l: Maleuole.

sp.speaker: Maleuole.
sp.p: Yaugh, goodman what dost thou there: Dukes Ganimed Juno's jealous of thy long stockings: shadow of a woman, what wouldst Weasel? thou lamb a Court: what dost thou bleat for? aye you smooth chinned Catamite

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.p: Come down thou rugged cur, and snarl here, I give thy dogged sullenness free liberty: trot about and bespurtle whom thou pleasest.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: I will come among you, you Goatish blooded Toderers, as Gum into Taffeta, to fret, to fret: I will fall like a sponge into water to suck up; to suck up. Howl again. I will pray, and come to you.

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.p: This Maleuole is one of the most prodigious affections that ever conversed with nature; A man, or rather a monster; more discontent than Lucifer when he was thrust out of the presence, his appetite is unsatiable as the Grave; as far from any content as from heaven, his highest delight is to procure others vexation, and therein he thinks he truly serves heaven; for it is his position, whosoever in this earth can be contented is a slave and damned; therefore does he afflict all in that to which they are most affected; the Elements struggle within him; his own soul is at variance within him: his speech is halter-worthy at all hours: I like him; i'faith, he gives good intelligence to my spirit, makes me understand those weaknesses which others flattery palliate: hark, they sing.

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.p: See he comes: now shall you hear the extremity of a Malcontent: he is as free as air: he blows over every man. And sir whence come you now?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: From the public place of much dissimulation;

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.l: What didst there?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Talk with a Usurer; take up at Interest.

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.l: I wonder what religion thou art?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Of a Soldiers religion.

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.l: And what dost think makes most Infidels now?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Sects, sects, I have seen seeming Piety change her robe so oft, that sure none but some arch-devil can shape her a new Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.l: Of a religious policy.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: But damnation on a politic religion.

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.p: But what is the common news abroad Maleuole, thou doggest rumour still.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Common news? why common words are, God save ye, Fare ye well: common actions, Flattery and Cozenage: common things, Women and Cuckolds: and how does my little Ferrard: a ye lecherous Animal, my little Ferret, he goes sucking up and down the Palace into every Hens nest like a Weasel: and to what dost thou addict thy time to now, more than to those Antique painted drabs that are still affected of young Courtiers, Flattery, Pride and Venery.

sp.speaker: Ferrard
sp.p: I study languages: who dost think to be the best linguist of our age?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Phew, the Devil let him possess thee, he will teach thee to speak all languages, most readily and strangely, and great reason marry, he is travelled greatly in the world; and is every where.

sp.speaker: Ferrar:
sp.l: Save in the Court.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Aye save in the Court: and how does my old Muckill overspread with fresh snow: thou half a man half a Goat, all a Beast: how does thy young wife old huddle?

sp.speaker: Bilio:
sp.l: Out you improvident rascal.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Do, kick thou hugely horned old Dukes Ox, good Master Make-pleece.

sp.speaker: Piet:
sp.l: How dost thou live now a days Maleuole

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Why like the Knight Saint Patrick Penlobrans, with killing a Spiders for my Ladies Monkey.

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.p: How dost spend the night, I hear thou never sleepest?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: O no, but dream the most fantastical: O heaven: O fubbery, fubbery

sp.speaker: Piet:
sp.l: Dream, what dreamest?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Why methinks I see that Seignior pawned his foot-cloth, that Metreza her Plate, this madam takes physic, that the other Monsieur may minister to her: here is a Pander jewelled: there a fellow in shift of Satin this day, that could not shift a shirt the other night, here a Paris supports that Hellen there is a Lady Guineuer bears up that sir Lancelot. Dreams, dreams, visions, fantasies, Chimeras, imaginations, tricks, conceits,

Sir Tristram Trimtram come a loft Jack a napes with a whim wham, here is a Knight of the land of Catito shall play at trap with any Page in Europe; Do the sword dance, with any Morris dancer in Christendom; ride at the Ring till the fin of his eyes look as blue as the welkin, and run the wild goose chase even with Pompey the huge.

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.l: You run.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: To the devil: now Seignior Guerchino; that thou from a most pitied prisoner shouldest grow a most loathed flatterer: Alas poor Celso, thy star is oppressed, thou art an honest Lord, it is pity.

sp.speaker: Equa:
sp.l: Is it pity?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Aye marry is it Philosophical Equato, and it is pity that thou being so excellent a Scholar by Art, shouldest be so ridiculous a fool by Nature: I have a thing to tell you Duke: bid them avaunt, bid them avaunt.

sp.speaker: Pietro:
sp.l: Leave us, leave us, now sir what is it?

body.stage: Exeunt all sauing Pietro and Maleuole

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Duke thou art a Beco, a Cornuto

sp.speaker: Piet:
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Thou art a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Piet:
sp.l: Speak; unshale him quick.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: With most tumbler-like nimbleness.

sp.speaker: Piet:
sp.l: Who? by whom? I burst with desire.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Mendoza is the man makes thee a horned beast;
Duke it is Mendoza cornutes thee.

sp.speaker: Piet:
sp.l: What conformance, relate, short, short.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: As a Lawyers beard,
sp.p: There is an old Crone in the Court, her name is Maquerelle, She is my Mistress sooth to say, and she doth ever tell me, Blurt a rhyme; blurt a rhyme; Maquerelle is a cunning Bawd, I am an honest villain, thy wife is a close Drab, and thou art a notorious Cuckold, farewell Duke.

sp.speaker: Piet:
sp.l: Stay, stay.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Dull, dull Duke, can lazy patience make lame revenge? O God for a woman to make a man that which God never created, never made.

sp.speaker: Piet:
sp.l: What did God never make?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: A Cuckold: To be made a thing that is hoodwinked with kindness whilst every rascal philips his brows; to have a Coxcomb with egregious horns pinned to a Lords back, every page sporting himself with delightful laughter, whilst he must be the last must know it; Pistols and Poniards, Pistols and Poniards.

sp.speaker: Piet:
sp.l: Death and damnation

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Lightning and thunder

sp.speaker: Piet:
sp.l: Vengeance and torture

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Catzo

sp.speaker: Piet:
sp.l: O revenge.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: I would damn him and all his generation, my own hands should do it; ha I would not trust heaven with my vengeance anything .

sp.speaker: Piet:
sp.p: Anything, anything Maleuole thou shalt see instantly what temper my spirit holds; farewell, remember, I forget thee not, farewell.

sp.speaker: Celso:
sp.l: My honoured Lord.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Peace, speak low; peace, O Celso, constant Lord,
Thou to whose faith I only rest discovered,
Thou one of full ten millions of men
That lovest virtue only for itself,
Thou in whose hands old OPS may put her soul;
Behold forever banished Altofront
This Genoas last years Duke. O truly noble,
I wanted those old instruments of state,
Dissemblance, and suspect: I could not time it Celso
My throne stood like a point in midst of a circle,
To all of equal nearness, bore with none:
Reigned all alike, so slept in fearless virtue,
Suspectless, too suspectless, till the crowd:
(Still liquorous of untried novelties)
Impatient with severer government:
Made strong with Florence: banished Altofront

sp.speaker: Celso:
sp.l: Strong with Florence, Aye , thence your mischief rose,
For when the daughter of the Florentine:
Was matched once with his Pietro now Duke,
No stratagem of state untried was left, till you of all

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Of all was quite bereft,
Alas Maria too close prisoned:
My true faithed duchess in the Citadel.

sp.speaker: Cel:
sp.l: I will still adhere, let us mutiny and die.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: O clime not a falling tower Celso,
It is well held desperation, no Zeal:
Hopeless to strive with fate (peace) Temporise.
Hope, hope, that never forsakest the wretchedest man,
Yet biddest me live, and lurk in this disguise,
What play I well the free breathed discontent?
sp.p: Why man we are all philosophical monarchs or natural fools, Celso the Courts afire, the Duchess sheets will smoke forth ere it be long: Impure Mendoza that sharpe nosed Lord, that made the cursed match linked Genoa with Florence now bred horns, the Duke which he now knows: Discord to malcontents is very Manna, when the ranks are burst, then scuffle Altophant

sp.speaker: Celso:
sp.l: Aye but durst.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: It is gone, it is swallowed like a mineral, some way it will work, phewt I will not shrink, he is resolute who can no lower sink.

sp.speaker: Cel:
sp.l: Yonder is Mendoza

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: True, the privy key.

sp.speaker: Cels:
sp.l: I take my leave sweet Lord.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: It is fit, away.

body.stage: Enter Mendoza with three or foure suters.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.p: Leave your suites with me, I can and will: attend my secretary, leave me.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Mendoza hark ye, hark ye, You are a treacherous villain, God be with ye.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: Out you base borne rascal.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: We are all the sons of heaven, though a Tripe wife were our mother; a you whoreson hot reined he Marmoset, Egistus didst ever hear of one Egistus?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Gistus?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Aye Egistus, he was a filthy incontinent Fleshmonger, such a one as thou art.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: Out grumbling rogue.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Orestes, beware Orestes.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: Out beggar.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I once shall rise,

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Thou rise?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Aye at the resurrection.
No vulgar seed, but once may rise, and shall,
No King so huge, but fore he die may fall.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Now good Elizium what a delicious heaven is it for a man to be in a Princes favour: o sweet God, o pleasure! o Fortune! o all thou best of life? what should I think? what say? what do? to be a favourite? a minion? to have a general timorous respect, observe a man, a stateful silence in his presence: solitariness in his absence, a confused ham and busy murmur of obsequious suitors training him; the cloth held up, and way proclaimed before him: Petitionary vassals licking the pavement with their slavish knees, whilst some odd palace Lamprels that engender with Snakes, and are full of eyes on both sides with a kind of insinuating humbleness fix all their lights upon his brow: O blessed state what a ravishing prospect doth the Olympus of favour yield; Death, I cornute the Duke: sweet women, most sweet Ladies, nay Angels; by heaven he is more accursed than a Devil that hates you, or is hated by you, and happier than a God that loves you, or is beloved by you; you preservers of mankind, life blood of society, who would live, nay who can live without you? O Paradise, how majestical is your austerer presence? how imperiously chaste is your more modest face? but O! how full of ravishing attraction is your pretty, petulant, languishing, lasciviously composed countenance: these amorous smiles, those soul warming sparkling glances; ardent as those flames that singed the world by heedless Phaeton; in body how delicate, in soul how witty, in discourse how pregnant, in life how wary, in favours how judicious, in day how sociable, and in night how? O pleasure unutterable, indeed it is most certain, one man cannot deserve only to enjoy a beauteous woman: but a Duchess? in despite of Phoebus I will write a Sonnet instantly in praise of her.

body.stage: Enter Ferneze vshering Aurelia, Emillia and Maquerelle bearing vp her traine, Beancha attending: all go out but Aurelia, Maquerelle and Ferneze

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: And is it possible? Mendoza slight me, possible?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Possible? what can be strange in him that is drunk with favour, Grows insolent with grace, speak Maquerelle, speak.

sp.speaker: Maq:
sp.p: To speak feelingly, more, more richly in solid sense than worthless words, give me those Jewels of your ears to receive my enforced duty, as for my part it is well known I can put up anything ; can bear patiently with any man: But when I heard he wronged your precious sweetness, I was enforced to take deep offence; it is most certain he loves Emilia with high appetite; and as she told me (as you know we women impart our secrets one to another), when she repulsed his suite, in that he was possessed with your endeared grace: Mendoza most ingratefully renounced all faith to you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nay, called you, speak Maquerelle speak .

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.l: By heaven witch? dried biscuit, and contested blushlessly he loved you but for a spurt or so.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: For maintenance.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.l: Advancement and regard.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O villain? O impudent Mendozo

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Nay he is the rustiest jade, the foulest mouthed knave in railing against our sex: he will rail against women.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: How? how?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.l: I am ashamed to speak it, Aye.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I love to hate him, speak .

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Why when Emillia scorned his base unsteadiness the black throated rascal scolded, and said.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.l: Troth it is too shameless,

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: What said he?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Why that at four women were fools, at fourteen Drabs, at forty Bawds, at fourscore witches, and a hundredth Cats.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O unlimitable impudency!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: But as for poor Fernezes fixed heart,
Was never shadeless meadow drier parched,
Under the scorching heat of heavens dog,
Than is my heart with your enforcing eyes.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.l: A hot simile.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Your smiles have been my heaven, your frowns my hell,
O pity then; Grace should with beauty dwell.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.l: Reasonable perfect byrlady.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I will love thee, be it but in despite,
Of that Mendozo, witch! Farneze, witch!
Ferneze thou art the Duchess favourite,
Be faithful, private, but it is dangerous,

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: His love is liveless, that for love fears breath,
The worst that is due to sin, O would it it were death.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Enjoy my favour, I will be sick instantly and take physic,
Therefore in depth of night, visit.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.l: Visit her chamber, but conditionally you shall not offend her bed: by this Diamond.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: By this Diamond

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.l: Nor tarry longer than you please: by this Ruby.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: By this Ruby.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.l: And that the door shall not creak.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And that the door shall not creak.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Nay but swear.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: By this purse.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Go to, I will keep your oaths for you: remember, visit.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Dried biscuit? look where the base wretch comes.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: Beauties life, Heavens model, Loves Queen.

sp.speaker: Maq:
sp.l: That is his AEmilia

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Natures triumph, best on earth.

sp.speaker: Maq:
sp.l: Meaning Emilia

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: Thou only wonder that the world hath seen.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.l: That is Emilia

sp.speaker: Aur:
sp.l: Must I then hear her praised? Mendozo.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.p: Madam, your excellency is graciously encountered; I have been writing passionate flashes in honour of

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Out villain, villain, O judgment, where have been my eyes? what bewitched election made me dote on thee? what sorcery made me love thee? but be gone, bury thy head: O that I could do more than loath thee: Hence worst of ill: No reason else, my reason is my will

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.p: Women? nay furies, nay worse, for they torment only the bad, but women good and bad. Damnation of mankind, breath hast thou praised them for this: And is it you Ferneze are wriggled into smock grace; sit sure, O that I could rail against these monsters in nature, models of hell, curse of the earth, women that dare attempt anything , and what they attempt they care not how they accomplish, without all premeditation or prevention; rash in asking, desperate in working, impatient in suffering, extreme in desiring, slaves unto appetite, mistresses in dissembling, only constant in unconstancy, only perfect in counterfeiting: their words are fained, their eyes forged, their sights dissembled, their looks counterfeit, their hair false, their given hopes deceitful, their very breath artificial: Their blood is their only God: Bad clothes, and old age, are only the Devils they tremble at: That I could rail now.

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.l: A mischief fill thy throat, thou foul jawed slave:
Say thy prayers.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: I have forgot them.

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.l: Thou shalt die.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: So shalt thou; I am heart mad.

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.l: I am horn mad.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: Extreme mad.

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.l: Monstrously mad.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.l: Why? thou, thou hast dishonoured my bed.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.p: I? come, come, sit, here is my bare heart to thee as steady as is this center to this glorious world, And yet hark thou art a Cornuto; but by me?

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.l: Yes slave by thee.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: Do not, do not with tart and spleenful breath,
Loose him can loose thee; I offend my Duke?
Bare record O ye dumb and raw aired nights,
How vigilant my sleepless eyes have been,
To watch the Traitor; record thou spirit of truth,
With what debasement I have thrown myself,
To under offices, only to learn
The truth, the party, time, the means, the place,
By whom, and when, and where thou wert disgraced:
And am I paid with slave? hath my intrusion
To places private, and prohibited,
Only to observe the closer passages:
Heaven knows with vows of revelation,
Made me suspected, made me deemed a villain?
What rogue hath wronged us?

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.l: Mendozo, I may err.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Err? it is too mild a name, but err and err,
Run giddy with suspect, for through me thou know,
That which most creatures save thyself do know:
Nay since my service hath so loathed reject,
Fore I will reveal, shalt find them clipped together.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Mendozo thou knowest I am a most plain breasted man.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: The fitter to make a Cornuto, would your brows were most plain too.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Tell me, indeed I heard thee rail?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: At women, true, why what cold phlegm could chose,
Knowing a Lord so honest, virtuous,
So boundless loving, bounteous, fair shaped, sweet,
To be contemned, abused, defamed, made Cuckold,
sp.p: Heart, I hate all women for it: sweet sheets, wax lights, Antique bed-posts, Cambric smocks, villainous curtains, Arras pictures, oiled hinges, and all ye tongue tied lascivious witnesses of great creatures wantonness: what salvation can you expect?

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.l: Wilt thou tell me?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Why you may find it yourself, observe, observe.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: I have not the patience, wilt thou deserve me; tell, give it.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Take it, why Farneze is the man, Ferneze I will prove it , this night you shall take him, in your sheets, will it serve.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: It will, my bosom is in some peace, till night.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: God how weak a Lord are you,
Why do you think there is no more but so?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Nay then will I presume to council you,
It should be thus; you with some guard upon the sudden
Break into the Princes chamber, I stay behind
Without the door, through which he needs must pass,
Ferneze flies, let him, to me he comes, he is killed
By me, observe by me, you follow, I rail,
And seem to save the body: Duchess comes
On whom (respecting her advanced birth,
And your fair nature), I know, nay I do know
No violence must be used. She comes, I storm,
I praise, excuse Ferneze, and still maintain
The Duchess honour, she for this loves me,
I honour you, shall know her soul, you mine,
Then naught shall she contrive in vengeance,
(As women are most thoughtful in revenge)
Of her Ferneze but you shall sooner know it
Than she can think it , thus shall his death come sure,
Your Duchess brain-caught; so your life secure.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: It is too well, my bosom, and my heart.
When nothing helps, cut off the rotten part.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Who cannot fain friendship, can never produce the effects of hatred: Honest fool Duke, subtle lascivious Duchess, silly novice ferneze; I do laugh at ye, my brain is in labour till it produce mischief, and I feel sudden throws, proofs sensible, the issue is at hand.
sp.l: As Bears shape young, so I will form my device,
Which grown proves horrid: Vengeance makes men wise.

body.stage: Enter Mendoza with a sconce, to observe Fernezes entrance, who whilest the Act is playing: Enter vnbraced two pages before him with lights, is met by Maquerelle and conuayedth. The pages are sent away.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: He is caught, the Woodcocks head is in the noose,
Now treads Ferneze in dangerous path of lust,
Swearing his sense is merely deified.
The fool grasps clouds, and shall beget Centaurs.
And now in strength of panting faint delight,
The Goat bids heaven envy him; good Goose,
I can afford thee nothing but the poor comfort of calamity, Pity.
Lust is like the plummets hanging on clock lines,
Will never have done till all is quite undone.
Such is the course salt sallow lust doth run,
Which thou shalt try; I will be revenged. Duke thy suspect,
Duchess thy disgrace, Ferneze thy rivalship
Shall have swift vengeance; nothing so holy,
No band of nature so strong,
No law of friendship so sacred,
But I will profane, burst, violate,
Fore I will endure disgrace, contempt and poverty:
Shall I, whose very hum, struck all heads bare;
Whose face made silence, creaking of whose shoe
Forced the most private passages fly ope,
Scrape like a servile dog at some latched door?
Learn now to make a leg? and cry beseech ye,
Pray ye is such a Lord within? be awed
At some odd ushers scoffed formality?
First sear my brains: Vnde cadis non quo refert
My heart cries perish all, how? how? what fate?
Can once avoid revenge, that is desperate,
I will to the Duke; if all should ope, if? tush
Fortune still dotes on those who cannot blush.

body.stage: Enter Maleuole at one doore, Beancha, Emilia and Maquerelle at the other doore.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Bless ye cast a Ladies: have Dipsas, how dost thou old Cole?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.l: Old Cole?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Aye old Cole, methinks thou liest like a brand under billets of green wood. He that will inflame a young wenches heart, let him lay close to her: an old Cole that hath first been fired a panderess, my half burnt lint, who though thou canst flame thyself, yet art able to set a thousand virgins tapers afire: and how does Ianiuere thy husband, my little periwinkle, is he troubled with the cough of the lungs still, does he hawk a-nights still, he will not bite.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: No by my troth, I took him with his mouth empty of old teeth.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: And he took thee with thy belly full of young bones, marry he took his maim by the stroke of his enemy.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.l: And I mine by the stroke of my friend:

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: The close stock, o mortal wench: Lady have ye now no restoratives for your decayed Iason, look ye, Crabs guts baked, distilled Ox pith, the pulverised hairs of a Lions upper lip, jelly of Cock-sparrows, He Monkeys marrow, or powder of fox stones; and whither are all you ambling now?

sp.speaker: Beancha
sp.l: Why to bed, to bed.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Do your husbands lie with ye?

sp.speaker: Beancha
sp.l: That were country fashion in faith.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Have ye no foregoers about you: come, whither in good deed law now?

sp.speaker: Beancha
sp.p: In good indeed law now, to eat the most miraculously, admirably, astonishable composed Posset with three Curds, without any drink: will ye help me with a he Fox: here is the Duke.

body.stage: Enter Duke Pietro Count Celso Count Equato, Bilioso, Ferrard and Mendoza

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.l: The night grows deep and foul, what hour is it?

sp.speaker: Celso
sp.l: Upon the stroke of twelve.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Save ye Duke.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: From thee, begone I do not love thee, let me see thee no more, we are displeased.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Why God be with thee, heaven hear my curse,
May thy wife and thee live long together.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: Be gone sirrah.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: When Arthur first in Court began, Agamemnon Menelaus, was ever any Duke a Cornuto

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: Begone hence.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: What religion wilt thou be of next?

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: Out with him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: With most servile patience time will come,
When wonder of thy error will strike dumb,
Thy bezzled sense, slaves I favour, I marry shall he, rise,
Good God how subtle Hell doth flatter vice,
Mounts him aloft, and makes him seem to fly,
As fowl the Tortoise mocked, who to the sky,
The ambitious shell fish raised; the end of all,
Is only , that from height he might dead fall.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: It shall be so.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: It must be so, for where great States revenge,
It is requisite the parts with piety
And soft respect forbears, be closely dogged,
Lay one into his breast shall sleep with him,
Feed in the same dish, run in self faction,
Who may dissever any shape of danger;
For once disgraced, discovered in offence,
It makes man blushless, and man is (all confess)
More prone to vengeance than to gratefulness.
Favours are writ in dust, but stripes we feel,
Depraved nature stamps in lasting steel.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: You shall be leagued with the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Equato
sp.l: The plot is very good.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: You shall both kill, and seem the course to save.

sp.speaker: Ferrard.
sp.l: A most fine brain trick.

sp.speaker: Celso
sp.l: Of a most cunning knave.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: My Lords, the heavy action we intend,
Is death and shame, two of the ugliest shapes
That can confound a soul; think, think of it:
I strike, but yet like him that against stone walls
Directs his shafts, rebounds in his own face,
My Ladies shame is mine; O God it is mine.
Therefore I do conjure all secrecy,
Let it be as very little as may be; pray ye, as may be.
Make frightless entrance, salute her with soft eyes,
Strain naught with blood, only Ferneze dies,
But not before her brows: O Gentlemen,
God knows I love her; nothing else, but this,
I am not well. If grief that sucks veins dry,
Rivals the skin, casts ashes in men's faces,
Bedulls the eye, unstrengthens all the blood:
Chance to remove me to another world,
As sure I once must die: let him succeed:
I have no child; all that my youth begot,
Hath been your loves, which shall inherit me:
Which as it ever shall, I do conjure it.
Mendoza may succeed, he is nobly borne,
With me of much desert.

sp.speaker: Celso
sp.l: Much.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: Your silence answers I,
I thank you, come on now, o that I might die
Before her shame is displayed, would I were forced
To burn my fathers Tomb, unhill his bones,
And dash them in the dirt, rather than this:
This both the living and the dead offends:
Sharpe surgery where naught but death amends.

body.stage: Enter Maquerelle, Emilia and Beancha with the posset.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.l: Even here it is, three curds in three regions individually distinct.
Most methodically according to art composed without any drink.

sp.speaker: Bean:
sp.l: Without any drink.

sp.speaker: Maq:
sp.l: Upon my honour, will ye sit and eat.

sp.speaker: Emil:
sp.l: Good, the composure, the receipt, how is it:

sp.speaker: Maq:
sp.p: It is a pretty pearl, by this pearl, (how dost with me), thus it is, seven and thirty yolks of Barbary hens eggs, eighteen spoonfuls and a half of the juice of cock-sparrow bones, one ounce, three drams, four scruples, and one quarter of the Syrup of Ethiopian Dates, sweetened with three quarters of a pound of pure Candid Indian Eringos strowed over with the powder of Pearl of America, Amber of Cataia, and Lamb stones of Muscouia

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Trust me the ingredients are very cordial, and no question good, and most powerful in operation.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: I know not what you mean by restoration, but this it doth, it purifieth the blood, smootheth the skin, enliveneth the eye, strengtheneth the veins, mundifieth the teeth, comforteth the stomach, fortifieth the back , and quickeneth the wit; that is all.

sp.speaker: Emil:
sp.p: By my troth I have eaten but two spoonfuls, and methinks I could discourse most swiftly and wittily already.

sp.speaker: Maq:
sp.l: Have you the art to seem honest?

sp.speaker: Bean:
sp.l: I thank advise and practise.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Why then eat me of this posset, quicken your blood, and preserve your beauty, do you know doctor Plaster-face, by this curd he is the most exquisite in forging of veins, sprightning of eyes, dying of hair, sleeking of skins, blushing of cheeks, surpheling of breasts, blanching and bleaching of teeth, that ever made an old lady gracious by torch-light: by this curd law.

sp.speaker: Be:
sp.l: Well we are resolved, what God has given us we will cherish.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Cherish anything saving your husband, keep him not too high, least he leap the pale: but for your beauty, let it be your Saint, bequeath two hours to it every morning in your closet: I have been young, and yet in my conscience I am not above five and twenty, but believe me, preserve and use your beauty; for youth and beauty once gone, we are like Beehives without honey: out a fashion, apparel that no man will wear, therefore use me your beauty.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Aye but men say.

sp.speaker: Maq:
sp.p: Men say, let men say what they will, life a woman, they are ignorant of your wants, the more in years, the more in perfection they grow: if they lose youth and beauty, they gain wisdom and discretion: But when our beauty fades, goodnight with us: there cannot be an uglier thing to see, than an old woman, from which, O pruning, pinching, and painting, deliver all sweet beauties.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Hark, music.

sp.speaker: Maq:
sp.p: Peace, it is in the Duchess bedchamber, good rest most prosperously graced Ladies.

sp.speaker: Emil:
sp.l: God night sentinel.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Night dear Maquerelle

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.l: May my possets operation send you my wit and honesty,
And me your youth and beauty: the pleasingest rest.

body.stage: Whilest the song is singing, enter Mendoza with his sword drawne, standing readie to murder Ferneze as he flies from the Dutches chamber.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Strike, Strike.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Save my Ferneze O save my Ferneze

body.stage: Enter Ferneze in his shirt, and is receiued vpon Mendozas sword.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Follow, pursue.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O save Ferneze

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Pierce, pierce, thou shallow fool drop there.
He that attempts a Princes lawless love,
Must have broad hands, close heart with Argos eyes,
And back of Hercules or else he dies.

body.stage: Enter Aurelia Duke Pietro, Ferrard, Bilioso, Celso and Equato

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: Stand off, forbear, ye most uncivil Lords.

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.l: Strike.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Do not; tempt not a man resolved,
Would you inhumane murtherers more than death?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O poor Ferneze

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: Alas, now all defence too late.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: He is dead.

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.l: I am sorry for our shame: go to your bed:
Weep not too much, but leave some tears to shed
When I am dead.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: What weep for thee? my soul no tears shall find.

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.l: Alas, alas, that women's souls are blind.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: Betraye such beauty? murther such youth? contemn civility.
He loves him not that rails not at him.

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.p: Thou canst not move us: we have blood enough.
sp.l: And please you Lady we have quite forgot
All your defects: if not, why then.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Not.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Not: the best of rest, good night.

sp.speaker: Aur:
sp.l: Despite go with thee.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: Madam, you have done me foul disgrace.
You have wronged him much, loves you too much.
Go to; your soul knows you have.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I think I have.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Do you but think so?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Nay, sure I have, my eyes have witnessed thy lover
Thou hast stood too firm for me.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Why tell me fair cheeked Lady, who even in tears,
art powerfully beauteous, what unadvised passion
Struck ye into such a violent heat against me?
Speak, what mischief wronged us? what devil injured us?
Speak.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: That thing never worthy of the name of man; Ferneze
Ferneze swore thou lovest Emilia
Which to advance with most reproachful breath,
Thou both didst blemish and denounce my love.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Ignoble villain, did I for this bestride
Thy wounded limbs; for this? O God for this?
Sunk all my hopes, and with my hopes my life,
Ripped bare my throat unto the hangman's axe.
Thou most dishonoured trunk Emillia
By life I know her not -- Emillia
Did you believe him?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Pardon me, I did.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Did you? and thereupon you graced him.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I did.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: Took him to favour, nay even clasped with him.

sp.speaker: Aur:
sp.l: Alas I did.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: This night?

sp.speaker: Aur:
sp.l: This night.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: And in your lustful twines the Duke took you?

sp.speaker: Aur:
sp.l: A most sad truth.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: O God O God how we dull honest souls,
Heavy brained men are swallowed in the bogs
Of a deceitful ground, whilst nimble bloods,
Light jointed spirits spent, cut good men's throats,
And scape; alas, I am too honest for this age,
Too full of phlegm, and heavy steadiness:
Stood still whilst this slave cast a noose about me;
Nay then to stand in honour of him and her,
Who had even sliced my heart.

sp.speaker: Aur:
sp.l: Come, I did err, and am most sorry, I did err.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: Why we are both but dead, the Duke hates us .
And those whom Princes do once groundly hate,
Let them provide to die, as sure as fate,
Prevention is the heart of policy.

sp.speaker: Aur:
sp.l: Shall we murder him?

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: Instantly.

sp.speaker: Aur:
sp.l: Instantly? before he casts a plot?
Or further blaze my honours much known blot.
Let us murther him.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: I would do much for you, will ye marry me?

sp.speaker: Aur:
sp.l: I will make thee Duke: we are of Medices
Florence our friend, in court my faction
Not meanly strengthful; the Duke then dead,
we well prepared for change: the multitude
Irresolutely reeling, we enforce:
Our party seconded, the kingdom mazed,
No doubt of swift success, all shall be graced.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: You do consume me, we are resolute,
Tomorrow look for change rest confident.
It is now about the immodest waste of night,
The mother of moist dew with pallid light,
Spreads gloomy shades about the numbed earth.
Sleep, sleep, whilst we contrive our mischiefs birth;
This man I will get inhumed; farewell, to bed;
I kiss the pillow, dream, the Duke is dead.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: So, so, good night, how fortune dotes on impudence,
I am in private the adopted son of yon good Prince.
I must be Duke; why if I must, I must,
Most silly Lord, name me? O heaven
I see God made honest fools, to maintain crafty knaves:
The Duchess is wholly mine too; must kill her husband
To quit her shame; much; then marry her: I,
O I grow proud in prosperous treachery
As wrestlers clip, so I will embrace you all,
Not to support, but to procure your fall.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: God arrest thee.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: At whose suite?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: At the devils; ah you treacherous damnable monster
How dost? how dost, thou treacherous rogue?
Ah ye rascal, I am banished the Court sirrah.

sp.speaker: Mendoza
sp.l: prithee let us be acquainted, I do love thee faith.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: At your service, by the Lord law, shall us go to supper, let us be once drunk together, and so unite a most virtuously strengthened friendship, shall us Huguenot shall us?

sp.speaker: Mendoza
sp.l: Wilt fall upon my chamber tomorrow morn?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: As a raven to a dunghill; they say there is one dead here, pricked for the pride of the flesh.

sp.speaker: Mendoza
sp.l: Ferneze there he is, prithee bury him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: O most willingly, I mean to turn pure Rochel churchman, I.

sp.speaker: Mendoza
sp.l: Thou church man why? why?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Because I will live lazily, rail upon authority, deny kings supremacy in things indifferent, and be a Pope in mine own parish.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: Wherefore dost thou think churches were made?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: To scour plough shares, I have seen oxen plough up Altars: Et nunc seges vbi Sion fuit

sp.speaker: Mendoza
sp.l: Strange.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nay monstrous, I have seen a sumptuous steeple turned to a stinking privy; more beastly, the sacredest place made a dogs kennel: nay most inhumane, the stoned coffins of long dead christians burst up, and made hogs troughs Hic finis Priami Shall I have some sack and cheese at thy chamber? Good night good mischievous incarnate devil, good night Mendoza ah you inhumane villain, goodnight, night fub.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Good night: tomorrow morn.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Aye , I will come friendly Damnation, I will come: I do descry cross points, honesty and court ship, straddle as far asunder, as a true Frenchman's legs.

sp.speaker: Ferneze
sp.l: O

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Proclamations, more proclamations.

sp.speaker: Ferneze
sp.l: O a Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Hark, lust cries for a Surgeon, what news from Limbo
How doth the grand cuckold Lucifer

sp.speaker: Ferneze
sp.l: O help, help, conceal and save me.

body.stage: Ferneze stirres, and Maleuole helpes him up and conuayes him away.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Thy shame more than thy wounds do grieve me far,
Thy wounds but leave upon thy flesh some scar;
But fame never heals, still rankles worse and worse,
Such is of uncontrolled lust the curse.
Think what it is in lawless sheets to lie:
But O Ferneze what in lust to die.
Then thou that shame respects, O fly converse
With women's eyes, and lisping wantonness:
Stick candles against a virgin walls white back,
If they not burn, yet at the least they will black.
Come, I will convey thee to a private port,
Where thou shalt live ( O happy man) from court.
The beauty of the day begins to rise,
From whose bright for me Nights heavy shadow flies,
Now gins close plots to work, the Scene grows full,
And craves his eyes who hath a solid skull.

body.stage: Enter Pietro the Duke, Mendoza; count Equato and Bilioso

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: it is grown to youth of day, how shall we waste this light?
My heart is more heavy than a tyrants crown.
Shall we go hunt? Prepare for field.

sp.speaker: Mendoza
sp.l: Would ye could be merry.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: Would God I could: Mendoza bid them haste:

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: I would fain shift place; O vain relief
Sad souls may well change place, but not change grief:
As dear being struck she through many soils,
Yet still the shaft sticks fast, so;

sp.speaker: Bilioso
sp.l: A good old simile, my honest Lord.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: I am not much unlike to some sick man,
That long desired hurtful drink; at last
Swills in and drinks his last, ending at once
Both life and thirst: O would I never had known
My own dishonour good God that men should
Desire to search out that, which being found, kills all
Their joy of life, to taste the tree of knowledge,
And then be driven from out Paradise.
Canst give me some comfort?

sp.speaker: Bilioso
sp.p: My Lord, I have some books which have been dedicated to my honour, and I never read them, and yet they had very fine names: Physic for Fortune: Lozenges of sanctified sincerity very pretty works of Curates, Scriveners and Schoolmasters Marry I remember one Seneca, Lucius Anneus Seneca

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: Out upon him, he writ of Temperance and Fortitude, yet lived like a voluptuous epicure, and died like an effeminate coward. Haste thee to Florence: here, take our Letters, see them sealed; away; report in private to the honoured Duke, his daughters forced disgrace, tell him at length,
sp.l: We know, too much due complements advance,
There is naught that is safe and sweet but ignorance.

body.stage: Enter Maleuole in some freeze gowne, whilst Bilioso reades his Patent.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I cannot sleep, my eyes ill neighbouring lids
Will hold no fellowship: O thou pale sober night,
Thou that in sluggish fumes all sense dost steep:
Thou that gives all the world full leave to play,
Unbendest the feebled veins of sweaty labour;
The galley slave, that all the toilsome day,
Tugs at his oar, against the stubborn wane,
Straining his rugged veins, snores fast:
The stooping scythe man that doth barb the field
Thou makest wink sure: in night all creatures sleep,
Only the Malcontent, that against his fate
Repines and quarrels, alas he is goodman tell clock,
His sallow jaw bones sink with wasting moan,
Whilst others beds are down, his pillows stone.

sp.speaker: Bili:
sp.l: Maleuole.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Elder of Israell thou honest defect of wicked nature and obstinate ignorance, when did thy wife let thee lie with her?

sp.speaker: Bili:
sp.l: I am going Ambassador to Florence

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Ambassador? now for thy countries honour: prithee do not put up mutton and porridge in thy cloak bag: thy young Lady wife goes to Florence with thee too, does she not?

sp.speaker: Bili:
sp.l: No, I leave her at the palace.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: At the palace? now discretion shield man, for Gods love let us have no more cuckolds: Hymen begins to put off his saffron robe, keep thy wife in the state of grace, heart a truth, I would sooner leave my Lady singled in a Bordello than in the Genoa Palace, sin there appearing in her sluttish shape,
sp.l: Would soon grow loathsome, even to blushes sense,
Surfeit would cloak intemperate appetite,
Make the soul scent the rotten breath of lust.
When in an Italian lascivious palace, a Lady guardianless,
Left to the push of all allurement,
The strongest incitements to immodesty,
To have her bound, incensed with wanton sweets,
Her veins filled hie with heating delicates:
sp.p: Soft rest, sweet music, amorous Masquers, lascivious banquets, sin itself gilt over, strong fantasy tricking up strange delights, presenting it dressed pleasingly to sense, sense leading it unto the soul, confirmed with potent example, impudent custom, enticed by that great bawd Opportunity, thus being prepared, clap to her easy care, youth in good clothes, well shaped, rich, fair spoken, promising noble, ardent blood full, witty, flattering: Vlisses absent, O Ithacan chastest Penelope hold out.

sp.speaker: Bil:
sp.l: Mass I will think on it, farewell.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Farewell, take thy wife with thee, farewell.
To Florence um? it may prove good, it may,
And we may once unmask our brows.

sp.speaker: Cel:
sp.l: My honoured Lord.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Celso peace, how is it? speak low, pale fears suspect that hedges, walls and trees have ears: speak; how runs all?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Aye faith my Lord, that beast with many heads
The staggering multitude recoils apace,
Though through great men's envy, most men's malice,
Their much intemperate heat hath banished you.
Yet now they find envy and malice near,
Produce faint reformation.
The Duke, the too soft Duke lies as a block,
For which two tugging factions seem to saw,
But still the iron through the ribs they draw.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: I tell thee Celzo, I have ever found
Thy breast most far from shifting cowardice
And fearful baseness: therefore I will tell thee Celzo
I find the wind begins to come about,
I will shift my suite of fortune, I know the Florentine whose only force,
By marrying his proud daughter to this Prince,
Both banished me, and made this weak Lord Duke,
Will now forsake them all, be sure he will:
I will lie in ambush for conveniency,
Upon their severance to confirm myself.

sp.speaker: Cel:
sp.l: Is Ferneze interred?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Of that at leisure: he lives.

sp.speaker: Cel:
sp.l: But how stands Mendoza how is it with him?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Faith like a pair of snuffers, snibs filth in other men, and retains it in itself.

sp.speaker: Cel:
sp.p: He does fly from public notice methinks, as a hare does from hounds, the feet whereon he flies betrays him.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: I can track him Celso
O my disguise fools him most powerfully:
For that I seem a desperate Male content,
He fain would clasp with me; he is the true slave
That will put on the most affected grace,
For some vild second cause.

sp.speaker: Celso
sp.l: He is here.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: give place.
Illo, ho, ho, ho, art there old true penny?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Where hast thou spent thyself this morning? I see flattery in thine eyes, and damnation in thy soul. Ha thou huge rascal

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Thou art very merry.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: As a scholar futuens gratis How doth the devil go with thee now?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Maleuole, thou art an arrant knave.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Who I, I have been a Sergeant man.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Thou art very poor.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: As Iob an Alchemist, or a Poet.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: The Duke hates thee.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: As Irishmen do bum cracks.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: Thou hast lost his amity.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: As pleasing as maids lose their virginity.

sp.speaker: Me:
sp.l: Would thou wert of a lusty spirit, would thou wert noble.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Why sure my blood gives me I am noble, sure I am of noble kind; for I find myself possessed with all their qualities; love Dogs, Dice, and Drabs, scorn wit in stuff clothes, have beat my Shoemaker, knocked my Seamsters, cuckold my Apothecary, and undone my Tailor. Noble, why not? since the Stoic said, Neminem seruum non ex vegibus, neminem regem non ex seruis esse oriundum only busy fortune touses, and the provident chances blends them together; I will give you a simile; Did you ere see a well with two buckets, whilst one comes up full to be emptied, another goes down empty to be filled; such is the state of all humanity: why look you, I may be the son of some Duke; for believe me, intemperate lascivious bastardy makes Nobility doubtful: I have a lusty daring heart Mendoza

sp.speaker: Mendo:
sp.p: Let us grasp, I do like thee infinitely, wilt enact one thing for me?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Shall I get by it?
Command me, I am thy slave, beyond death and hell.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: Murther the Duke.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: My hearts wish, my souls desire, my fantasies dream,
My bloods longing, the only height of my hopes, how
O God how? how my united spirits throng together,
So strengthen my resolve.

sp.speaker: Mendoza.
sp.l: The Duke is now a-hunting .

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Excellent, admirable, as the devil would have it, lend me, lend me, Rapier, Pistol, Crossbow; so, so, I will do it.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Then we agree.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: As Lent and fishmongers, come a cape a pe, how in form

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Know that this weak brained duke, who only stands on Florence stilts, hath out of witless zeal made me his heir, and secretly confirmed the wreathe to me after his life's full point.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Upon what merit?

sp.speaker: Mendoza
sp.p: Merit by heaven I horn him, only Fernezdes death gave me states life: tut we are politic, he must not live now.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No reason marry: but how must he die now?

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.p: My utmost project is to murder the Duke, that I might have his state, because he makes me his heir; to banish the duchess, that I might be rid of a cunning Lacedemonian, because I know Florence will forsake her, and then to marry Maria the banished duke Altofronts wife, that her friends might strengthen me and my faction; this is all law.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Do you love Maria

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.p: Faith no great affection, but as wise men do love great women, to ennoble their blood, and augment their revenue: to accomplish this now, thus now. The Duke is in the forest next the Sea, single him, kill him, hurl him in the main, and proclaim thou sawest wolves eat him.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Um, not so good: methinks when he is slain, to get some hypocrite, some dangerous wretch that is muffled, or with fained holiness, to swear he heard the duke on some steep cliff lament his wife's dishonour, and in an agony of his hearts torture hurled his groaning sides into the swollen sea: This circumstance well made, sounds probable: and hereupon the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.p: May well be banished: O unpeerable invention are, Thou god of policy, it honeys me.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Then fear not for the wife of Altofront I will close to her.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.p: Thou shalt, thou shalt, our excellency is pleased: why wert not thou an Emperor? when we are Duke, I will make thee some great man sure.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nay, make me some rich knave, and I will make myself some great man.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: In thee be all my spirit, retain ten souls, unite thy virtual powers; resolve, ha, remember greatness: heart, farewell.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: The fate of all my hopes in thee doth dwell.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Celzo didst hear? O heaven, didst hear?
Such devilish mischief, sufferest thou the world
Carouse damnation even with greedy swallow,
And still dost wink, still does thy vengeance slumber:
If now thy brows are clear, when will they thunder

body.stage: Enter Pietro, Ferrard, Prepasso and three Pages.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: The dogs are at a fault.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: Would God nothing but the dogs were at it? let the deer pursue safely, the dogs follow the game, and do you follow the dogs; as for me, it is unfit one beast should hunt an other; I have one chaseth me: if it please you, I would be rid of you a little.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p: Would your grief would as soon leave you as we to quietness.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: I thank you; boy, what dost thou dream of now?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Of a dry summer my Lord, for here is a hot world towards: but my Lord, I had a strange dream last night.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: What strange dream?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Why methought I pleased you with singing, and then I dreamt you gave me that short sword.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: Prettily begged: hold thee, I will prove thy dream true, take it .

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: My duty: but still I dreamt on my Lord, and methought, if it shall please your excellency, you would needs out of your royal bounty give me that jewel in your hat.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: O thou didst but dream boy, do not believe it, dreams prove not always true, they may hold in a short sword, but not in a jewel. But now sir, you dreamt you had pleased me with singing, make that true as I have made the other.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Faith my Lord, I did but dream, and dreams you say prove not always true: they may hold in a good sword, but not in a good song: the truth is, I have lost my voice.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: Lost thy voice, how?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: With dreaming faith, but here is a couple of Sirenical rascals shall enchant ye: what shall they sing my good Lord?

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: Sing of the nature of women, and then the song shall be surely full of variety; old crochets and most sweet closes, it shall be humorous, grave, fantastic, amorous, melancholy, sprightly, one in all, and all in one.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: All in one?

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: by Our Lady too many; sing, my speech grows culpable of unthrifty idleness, sing.

body.stage: Enter Maleuole with Crossebow and Pistoll.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: A, so, so, sing, I am heavy, walk off, I shall talk in my sleep; walk off.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Brief, brief, who? the Duke? good heaven that fools should stumble upon greatness do not sleep Duke, give ye good morrow: you must be brief Duke; I am feed to murther thee, start not: Mendoza, Mendoza hired me, here is his gold, his pistol, crossbow, and sword, it is all as firm as earth: O fool, fool, choked with the common maze of easy idiots, Credulity, make him thine heir: what thy sworn murtherer?

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: O can it be?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Can?

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: Discovered he not Ferneze

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Yes; but why, but why, for love to thee; much, much, to be revenged upon his rival, who had thrust his jaws awry, who being slain, supposed by thine own hands; defended by his sword, made thee most loathsome, him most gracious with thy loose Princess, thou closely yielding egress and regress to her, madest him heir, whose hot unquiet lust strait toused thy sheets, and now would seize thy state, politician, wise man, death to be led to the stake like a bull by the horns, to make even kindness cut a gentle throat; life, why art thou numbed? thou foggy dullness, speak: lives not more faith in a home thrusting tongue than in these fencing tip tap Courtiers?

body.stage: Enter Celso with a Hermites gowne and beard.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Lord Maleuole if this be true.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: If? come shade thee with this disguise, if? thou shalt handle it, he shall thank thee for killing thyself, come follow my directions, and thou shalt see strange sleights.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: World whither wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Why to the devil: come, the morn grows late,
A steady quickness is the soul of state.

body.stage: Enter Maquarelle knocking at the Ladies doore.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Madam, Madam, are you stirring Madam? if you be stirring Madam, if I thought I should disturb ye.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: My Lady is up forsooth.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.l: A pretty boy, faith how old art thou?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: I think fourteen.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Nay, and ye be in the teens: are ye a gentleman borne? do you know me? my name is Madam Maquerelle I lie in the old cony court. See here the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.l: A fair day to ye Maquarelle

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Is the Duchess up yet Sentinel

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: O Ladies, the most abominable mischance, O dear Ladies, the most piteous disaster, Ferneze was taken last night in the Duchess chamber: alas the Duke catched him and killed him.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.l: Was he found in bed?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: O no, but the villainous certainty is, the door was not bolted, the tongue tied hatch held his peace: so the naked troth is, he was found in his shirt, whilst I like an arrant beast, lay in the outward chamber, heard nothing, and yet they came by me in the dark, and yet I felt them not, like a senseless creature as I was. O beauties, look to your busk points, if not chastely, yet charily: be sure the door be bolted: is your Lord gone to Florence

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.l: Yes Maquarelle

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: I hope you will find the discretion to purchase a fresh gown for his return: Now by my troth beauties I would have ye once wife: he loves ye, pish: he is witty; bubble: fair proportioned, meaw: nobly borne, wind: let this be still your fixed position, esteem me every man according to his good gifts, and so ye shall ever remain most dear, and most worthy to be most dear Ladies.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.l: Is the Duke returned from hunting yet?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.l: They say not yet.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.l: It is now in midst of day.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: How bears the Duchess with this blemish now?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Faith boldly, strongly defies defame, as one that has a Duke to her father. And there is a note to you: be sure of a stout friend in a corner, that may always awe your husband. Mark the behaviour of the Duchess now: she dares defame, cries Duke, do what thou canst, I will quite mine honour: nay, as one confirmed in her own virtue against ten thousand mouths that mutter her disgrace, she is presently for dances.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.l: For dances?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.l: Most true.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Most strange: see, here is my servant young Ferrard how many servants thinkst thou I have Maquerelle

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: The more, the merrier: it was well said; use your servants as you do your smocks, have many, use one, and change often, for that is most sweet and court-like.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Save ye fair Ladies, is the Duke returned?

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.l: Sweet sir no voice of him as yet in Court.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: It is very strange.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.l: And how like you my servant Maquerelle

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: I think he could hardly draw Vlisses bow, but by my fidelity, were his nose narrower, his eyes broader, his hands thinner, his lips thicker, his legs bigger, his feet lesser, his hair blacker, and his teeth whiter, he were a tolerable sweet youth in faith. And he will come to my chamber, I will read him the fortune of his beard.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Not yet returned I fear, but
The Duchess approacheth.

body.stage: Enter Mendoza supporting the Dutchesse, Guerino the Ladies that are on the stage rise: Ferrard Ushers in the Dutches, and then takes a Lady to treade a measure.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: We will dance, music, we will dance.

sp.speaker: Guer.
sp.l: Les quanto (Lady) penses bien, passa regis or Beanchaes brawl.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: We have forgot the brawl.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: So soon? it is wonder.

sp.speaker: Guer.
sp.p: Why? it is but two singles on the left, two on the right, three doubles forward, a traverse of six round: do this twice, three singles side, galliard trick of twenty, curranto pace; a figure of eight, three singles broken down, come up, meet two doubles, fall back, and then honour.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O Dedalus thy maze, I have quite forgot it.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Trust me so have I, saving the falling back, and then honour.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Music, music.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Who saw the Duke? the Duke?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Music.

sp.speaker: Pre:
sp.l: The Duke, is the Duke returned?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Music.

sp.speaker: Cel:
sp.l: The Duke is either quite invisible, or else is not.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: we are not pleased with your intrusion upon our private retirement: we are not pleased: you have forgot yourselves .

sp.speaker: Celso
sp.l: Boy, thy master: where is the Duke?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Alas, I left him burying the earth with his spread joyless limbs: he told me, he was heavy, would sleep, bid me walk off, for that the strength of fantasy, oft made him talk in his dreams: I straight obeyed, nor ever saw him since: but wheresoever he is, he is sad.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Music, sound high, as is our heart, sound high.

body.stage: Enter Maleuole and Pietro disguised like an Hermite.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: The Duke, peace, the Duke is dead.

sp.speaker: Aur:
sp.l: Music.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Is it music?

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: Give proof.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Cel:
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Pre:
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Rest in peace as the Duke does , quietly sit: for my own part I beheld him but dead; that is all: marry here is one can give you a more particular account of him.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Speak holy father, nor let any brow within this presence fright thee from the truth: speak confidently and freely.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: We attend.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Now had the mounting suns all ripening wings
Swept the cold sweat of night from earths dank breast,
When I whom men call Hermit of the Rock,
Forsook my Cell, and clambered up a cliff,
Against whose Base, the heady Neptune dashed
His high curled brows: there it was I cased my limbs,
When lo, my entrails melted with the moan
Someone , who far above me was climbed, did make:
I shall offend.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: Not.

sp.speaker: Aur:
sp.l: On.

sp.speaker: Piet:
sp.l: Methinks I hear him yet, O female faith
Go sow the ingrateful sand, and love a woman:
And do I live to be the scoff of men?
To be the wittol cuckold, even to hug my poison?
Thou knowest O truth
Sooner hard steel will melt with Southern wind;
A Sea man's whistle calm the Ocean;
A town on fire be extinct with tears,
Than women vowed to blushless impudence,
With sweet behaviour and soft minioning,
Will turn from that where appetite is fixed.
O powerful blood how thou dost slave their soul,
I washed an Ethiope, who for recompense,
Sullied my name. And must I then be forced
To walk, to live thus black: must, must, sigh,
He that can bear with must, he cannot die.
With that he sighed too passionately deep,
That the Dull air even groaned: at last he cries,
Sink shame in seas, sink deep enough: so dies.
For then I viewed his body fall and souse
Into the foamy main, O then I saw
That which methinks I see; it was the Duke,
Whom straight the nicer stomached sea
Belched up: but then.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Then came I in, but alas all was too late,
For even straight he sunk.

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.l: Such was the Dukes sad fate.

sp.speaker: Cel:
sp.l: A better fortune to our Duke Mendoza

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: Mendoza.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: A guard, a guard, we full of hearty tears,
For our good fathers loss,
For so we well may call him:
Who did beseech your loves for our succession,
Cannot so lightly over jump his death,
As leave his woes revengeless:
Woman of shame.
We banish thee forever to the place,
From whence this good man comes,
Nor permit on death unto the body any ornament:
But base as was thy life, depart away.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Mendo.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Villain hear me.

body.stage: Prepasso and Guerino lead away the Dutches.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Be gone, my Lords address to public counsel,
it is most fit,
The train of Fortune is borne up by wit.
Away, our presence shall be sudden, haste.

body.stage: All depart sauing Mendoza, Maleuole and Pietro

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Now you egregious devil, Ha, ye murthering Politician, how dost Duke? how dost look now? brave Duke in faith.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: How did you kill him?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Flatted his brains out, then soused him in the briny sea.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: Brained him and drowned him too?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: O it was best, sure work:
sp.p: For he that strikes a great man, let him strike home, or else ware, he will prove no man: shoulder not a huge fellow, unless you may be sure to lay him in the kennel.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: A most sound brain pan.
I will make you both Emperors.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Make us christians, make us christians.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: I will hoist ye, ye shall mount.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: To the gallows say ye? Come: Prmium incertum petit certum scelus How stands the Progress?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: here, take my ring unto the Citadel,
Have entrance to Maria the grave Duchess
Of banished Altofront Tell her we love her:
Omit no circumstance to grace our person, do it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I will make an excellent pander: Duke farewell, due, adieu Duke.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Take Maquarelle with thee; for it is found,
None cuts a diamond, but a diamond.
Hermit thou art a man for me, my confessor:
O thou selected spirit, borne for my good,
Sure thou wouldst make an excellent Elder in a deformed church.
Come, we must be inward, thou and I all one.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: I am glad I was ordained for ye.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Go to then, thou must know that Maleuole is a strange villain: dangerous, very dangerous: you see how broad he speaks, a gross jawed rogue, I would have thee poison him: he is like a corn upon my great toe, I cannot go for him; he must be cored out he must: wilt do it ha?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Anything, anything .

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Heart of my life, thus then to the Citadel,
Thou shalt consort with this Maleuole
There being at supper poison him:
It shall be laid upon Maria who yields love, or dies:
Scud quick like lightning.

sp.speaker: Tie.
sp.l: Good deeds crawl, but mischief flies.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Your devilships ring has no virtue, the buff captain, the sallow westfalian gammon faced zaza cries, stand out must have a stiffer warrant, or no pass into the Castle of Comfort.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.p: Command our sudden Letter: not enter? shat, what place is there in Genoa but thou shalt, into my heart, into my very heart: come, let us love, we must love, we two, soul and body.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: How didst like the Hermit? a strange Hermit sirrah.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: A dangerous fellow, very perilous: he must die.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Aye , he must die.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Thoust kill him: we are wise, we must be wise.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: And provident.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Yea provident; beware an hypocrite.
A Church man once corrupted, O avoid
A fellow that makes Religion his stalking horse,
He breeds a plague: thou shalt poison him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Ho, it is wondrous necessary: how?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: You both go jointly to the Citadel,
There sup there poison him: and Maria
Because she is our opposite, shall bear
The sad suspect, on which she dies, or loves us.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: I run.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: We that are great, our sole self good still moves us .
They shall die both, for their deserts craves more
Than we can recompense, their presence still
Embraids our fortunes with beholdingness,
Which we abhor like deed, not doer: then conclude,
They live not to cry out ingratitude.
One stick burns the other steel cuts steel alone:
It is good trust few, but O, it is best trust none.

body.stage: Enter Maleuole and Pietro still disguised, at seuerall doores.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: How do you? how dost Duke?

sp.speaker: Piet:
sp.l: O let the last day fall, drop, drop on our cursed heads;
Let heaven unclasp itself, vomit forth flames.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: O do not rant, do not turn player, there is more of them than can well live one by another already. What, art an infidel still?

sp.speaker: Pie:
sp.l: I am amazed, struck in a swoon with wonder: I am commanded to poison thee.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: I am commanded to poison thee at supper.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: At supper?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: In the Citadel.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.l: In the Citadel?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Cross capers, tricks, truth a heaven, he would discharge us as boys do eldern guns, one pellet to strike out another: of what faith art now?

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.l: All is damnation, wickedness extreme, there is no faith in man.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: In none but usurers and brokers, they deceive no man, men take them for blood suckers, and so they are: now God deliver me from my friends.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.l: Thy friends?

sp.speaker: Maleu.
sp.p: Yes, from my friends, for from mine enemies I will deliver myself. O, cut throat friendship is the rankest villainy: Mark this Mendoza mark him for a villain; but heaven will send a plague upon him for a rogue.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: O world

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: World it is the only region of death, the greatest shop of the Devil, the cruellest prison of men, out of the which none pass without paying their dearest breath for a fee, there is nothing perfect in it, but extreme extreme calamity, such as comes yonder.

body.stage: Enter Aurelia two Holberts before, and twoo after, supported by Celso and Ferrard, Aurelia in base mourning attire.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: To banishment, led on to banishment.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: Lady, the blessedness of repentance to you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Why? why? I can desire nothing but death, nor deserve anything but hell.
If heaven should give sufficiency of grace
To clear my soul, it would make heaven graceless:
My sins would make the stock of mercy poor;
O they would tire heavens goodness to reclaim them:
Judgment is just yet from that vast villain:
But sure he shall not miss sad punishment
Fore he shall rule. On to my cell of shame.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: My cell it is Lady, where instead of masks,
Music, tilts, tourneys, and such court-like shows,
The hollow murmur of the checkless winds
Shall groan again, whilst the unquiet sea
Shakes the whole rock with foamy battery:
There Usherless the air comes in and out:
There rheumy vault will force your eyes to weep,
Whilst you behold true desolation:
A rocky barrenness shall pierce your eyes,
Where all at once one reaches where he stands,
With brows the roof, both walls with both his hands.

sp.speaker: Aurelia
sp.l: It is too good, blessed spirit of my Lord,
O in what orb so ere thy soul is throned,
Behold me worthily most miserable:
O let the anguish of my contrite spirit
Entreat some reconciliation:
If not, joy, triumph in my just grief,
Death is the end of woes, and tears relief.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: Belike your Lord not loved you, was unkind.

sp.speaker: Aurelia
sp.l: O heaven
As the soul loved the body, so loved he,
It was death to him to part my presence,
Heaven to see me pleased:
Yet I, like to a wretch given over to hell,
Brake all the sacred rites of marriage,
To clip a base ungentle faithless villain.
O God, a very Pagan reprobate:
What should I say? ungrateful, throws me out,
For whom I lost soul, body, fame and honour:
But it is most fit; why should a better fate
Attend on any, who forsake chaste sheets,
Fly the embrace of a devoted heart.
Joined by a solemn vow fore God and man,
To taste the brackish blood of beastly lust,
In an adulterous touch? ravenous immodesty,
Insatiate impudence of appetite;
Look, here is your end, for mark what sap in dust,
What sin in good, even so much love in lust:
Joy to thy ghost, sweet Lord, pardon to me.

sp.speaker: Celso
sp.l: It is the dukes pleasure this night you rest in court.

sp.speaker: Aur:
sp.l: Soul lurk in shades, run shame from brightsome skies,
In night the blind man misseth not his eyes.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Do not weep, kind cuckold, take comfort man, thy betters have been Beccoes: Agamemnon Emperor of all the merry Greeks that tickled all the true Troyans, was a Cornuto: Prince Arthur that cut off twelve Kings beards, was a Cornuto: Hercules whose back bore up heaven, and got forty wenches with child in one night.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: Nay it was fifty.

sp.speaker: Maleu.
sp.p: Faith forty is enough a conscience, yet was a Cornuto patience, mischief grows proud, be wise.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: Thou pinchest too deep, art too keen upon me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Tut, a pitiful Surgeon makes a dangerous sore, I will tent thee to the ground. Thinkest I will sustain myself by flattering thee, because thou art a Prince? I had rather follow a drunkard, and live by licking up his vomit, than by servile flattery.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: Yet great men have done it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Great slaves fear better than love , borne naturally for a coal basket, though the common usher of Princes presence fortune hath blindly given them better place, I am vowed to be thy affliction.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: prithee be, I love much misery, and be thou son to me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Because you are an usurping Duke.
Your Lordship is well returned from Florence

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.l: Well returned, I praise my horse.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: What news from the Florentines?

sp.speaker: Bilioso
sp.p: I will conceal the great Dukes pleasure, only this was his charge, his pleasure is, that his daughter die, Duke Pietro be banished, for banishing his bloods dishonour, and that Duke Altofront be reaccepted: this is all, but I hear Duke Pietro is dead.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Aye , and Mendoza is Duke, what will you do?

sp.speaker: Bilioso
sp.l: Is Mendoza strongest?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Yet he is.

sp.speaker: Bilioso
sp.l: Then yet I will hold with him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But if that Altofront should turn strait again ?

sp.speaker: Bilioso
sp.l: Why then I would turn strait again.
It is good run still with him that has most might:
I had rather stand with wrong, than fall with right.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: What religion will you be of now?

sp.speaker: Bili.
sp.l: Of the Dukes religion, when I know what it is.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: O Hercules

sp.speaker: Bili.
sp.l: Hercules? Hercules was the son of Jupiter and Alkmena

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Your lordship is a very wittol.

sp.speaker: Bilios.
sp.l: Wittol?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Aye , all wit.

sp.speaker: Bilios.
sp.l: Amphitrio was a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Your lordship sweats, your young Lady will get you a cloth for your old worships brows.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Here is a fellow to be damned, this is his inviolable maxim, flatter the greatest, and oppress the least: a whoreson flesh fly, that still gnaws upon the lean galled backs.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: Why dost then salute him?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: in faith as bawds go to church, for fashion sake: come, be not confounded, thou art but in danger to lose a dukedom: think this: This earth is the only grave and Golgotha wherein all things that live must rot: it is but the draught wherein the heavenly bodies discharge their corruption, the very muckhill on which the sublunary orbs cast their excrements: man is the slime of this dung pit, and Princes are the governors of these men: for, for our souls, they are as free as Emperors, all of one piece, there goes but a pair of shears betwixt an Emperor and the son of a bag piper, only the dying, dressing, pressing, glossing makes the difference: now what art thou like to lose?
sp.l: A Jailers office to keep men in bonds,
Whilst toil and treason, all life's good confounds.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: I here renounce forever regency:
O Altofront I wrong thee to supplant thy right:
To trip thy heels up with a devilish slight.
For which I now from throne am thrown, world tricks abjure:
For vengeance though it comes slow, yet it comes sure.
O I am changed; for herefore the dread power,
In true contrition I do dedicate,
My breath to solitary holiness,
My lips to prayer, and my breasts care shall be,
Restoring Altofront to regency.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Thy vows are heard, and we accept thy faith.

body.stage: Enter Ferneze and Celso. Altofront, Ferneze, Celso, Pietro.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Banish amazement; come, we four must stand full shock of
Fortune, be not so wonder stricken.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: Doth Ferneze live?

sp.speaker: Ferneze
sp.l: For your pardon.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: Pardon and love, give leave to recollect
My thoughts dispersed in wild astonishment:
My vows stand fixed in heaven, and from hence
I crave all love and pardon.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Who doubts of providence,
that sees this change, a hearty faith to all:
He needs must rise, can no lower fall:
For still impetuous vicissitude
Touseth the world, then let no maze intrude
Upon your spirits: wonder not I rise;
For who can sink, that close can temporise?
The time grows ripe for action, I will detect
My privatest plot; lest ignorance fear suspect:
Let us close to counsel, leave the rest to fate,
Mature discretion is the life of state.

body.stage: Enter Maleuole and Maquarelle, at seuerall doores opposite, singing.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The Dutchman for a drunkard.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.l: The Daue for golden locks:

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The Irishman for Vsquebath.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.l: The Frenchman for the pox

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: O thou art a blessed creature, had I a modest woman to conceal, I would put her to thy custody, for no reasonable creature would ever suspect her to be in thy company: ha, thou art a melodious Maquerelle thou picture of a woman, and substance of a beast. And how dost thou think a this transformation of state now?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Very very well, for we women always note, the falling of the one, is the rising of the other: some must be fat, some must be lean, some must be fools, and some must be Lords, some must be knaves, and some must be officers: some must be beggars, some must be Knights: some must be cuckolds, and some must be citizens: as for example, I have two court dogs the most fawning curs, the one called Watch, the other Catch: now I, like lady Fortune, sometimes love this dog, sometimes raise that dog, sometimes favour Watch, most commonly fancy Catch: now that dog which I favour I feed, and he is so ravenous, that what I give he never chews it, gulps it down whole, without any relish of what he has , but with a greedy expectation of what he shall have: the other dog, now:

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: No more dog, sweet Maquarelle, no more dog: and what hope hast thou of the duchess Maria, will she stoop to the Dukes leer, will she cow thinkst?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Let me see, where is the sign now? have ye ere a calendar, where is the sign trow you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Sign why is there any moment in that?

sp.speaker: Maq.
