sp.p: O believe me a most secret power, look ye a Chaldean or an Assyrian, I am sure it was a most sweet Jew told me, court any woman in the right sign, you shall not miss: but you must take her in the right vain then: as when the sign is in Pisces, a Fishmongers wife is very sociable: in Cancer, a Precisians wife is very flexible: in Capricorn, a Merchants wife hardly holds out: in Libra, a Lawyers wife is very tractable, especially, if her husband be at the term: only in Scorpio it is very dangerous meddling: has the Duke sent any jewel, any rich stones?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Aye , I think those are the best signs to take a lady in. By your favour seignior, I must discourse with the Lady Maria, Altofronts duchess: I must enter for the Duke.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: She here shall give you interview: I received the guardship of this Citadel from the good Altofront and for his use I will keep it till I am of no use.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Wilt thou? O heavens, that a christian should be found in a Buff jerkin captain Conscience: I love thee Captain.
sp.l: We attend, and what hope hast thou of this Duchess easiness?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: it will go hard, she was a cold creature ever, she hated monkeys, fools, jesters, and gentlemen ushers extremely: she had the vild trick on it, not only to be truly modestly honourable in her own conscience, but she would avoid the least wanton carriage that might incur suspect, as God bless me, she had almost brought bed pressing out of fashion: I could scarce get a fine for the lease of a Ladies favour once in a fortnight.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Now in the name of immodesty, how many maiden heads hast thou brought to the block?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Let me see: heaven forgive us our misdeeds: here is the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: God bless thee Lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Out of thy company.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: We have brought thee tender of a husband.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I hope I have one already.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Nay, by mine honour Madam, as good have never a husband, as a banished husband, he is in an other world now. I will tell ye Lady, I have heard of a sect that maintained, when the husband was asleep , the wife might lawfully entertain another man: for then her husband was as dead, much more when he is banished.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Unhonest creature

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Pish, honesty is but an art to seem so: pray ye what is honesty? what is constancy? but fables fained, odd old fools chat, devised by jealous fools, to wrong our liberty.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Mully he that loves thee, is a Duke, Mendoza he will maintain thee royally, love thee ardently, defend thee powerfully, marry thee sumptuously, and keep thee in despite of Rosciclere or Dozel del Phoebo there is jewels, if thou wilt, so; if not, so.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Captain, for God, sake save poor wretchedness
From tyranny of lustful insolence:
Enforce me in the deepest dungeon dwell
Rather than here, here round about is hell.
O my dearest Altofront where ere thou breath,
Let my, soul sink into the shades beneath,
Before I stain thine honour, this thou hast;
And long as I can die, I will live chaste.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Against him that can enforce, how vain is strife?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: She that can be enforced has has never a knife?
She that through force her limbs with lust enrols
Wants Cleopatres asps and Portiaes coals
God amend you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Now the fear of the devil forever go with thee. Marquerelle I tell thee, I have found an honest woman faith I perceive when all is done, there is of women, as of all other things: some good, most bad: some saints, some sinners: for as nowadays, no Courtier but has his mistress, no Captain but has his cockatrice, no Cuckold but has his horns, and no fool but has his feather: even so, no woman but has her weakness and feather too, no sex but has his: I can hunt the letter no farther: God, how loathsome this toying is to me, that a duke should be forced to fool it: well, Stultorum plena sunt omnia better play the fool Lord, than be the fool Lord: now, where is your slights Madam Maquarelle

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Why, are ye ignorant that it is said, a squeamish affected niceness is natural to women, and that the excuse of their yielding, is only (forsooth) the difficult obtaining. You must put her to it : women are flax, and will fire in a moment.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why, was the flax put into thy mouth, and yet thou? thou set fire? thou inflame her?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Marry, but I will tell ye now, you were too hot.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The fitter to have inflamed the flax-woman.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.l: You were too boisterous, spleen, for indeed.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Go, go, thou art a weak panderess, now I see.
Sooner earths fire heaven itself shall waste,
Than all with heat can melt a mind that is chaste.
sp.p: Go thou the Dukes lime twig, I will make the Duke turn thee out of thine office. what, not get one touch of hope, and had her at such advantage.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Now a my conscience, now I think in my discretion, we did not take her in the right sign, the blood was not in the true vein, sure.

body.stage: Enter Prepasso and Ferrard two pages with lights, Celso and Equato Mendozo iu Dukes roabs. Bilioso and Guerrino Exeunt all sauing Maleuole

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: On on, leave us leave us : stay, where is the Hermit?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: With Duke Pietro, with Duke Pietro

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Is he dead? is he poisoned?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Dead as the Duke is,

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Good, excellent: he will not blab, secureness lives in secrecy, come hither, come hither.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Thou hast a certain strong villainous sent about thee, my nature cannot endure.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Sent man? what returns Maria what answer to our suit?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Cold frosty, she is obstinate,

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: Then she is but dead, it is resolute, she dies,
Black deed only through black deed, safely flees.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Pew, per scelera semper sceleribus tutum est iter

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: What art a scholar? Art a politician? sure thou art an arrant knave.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Who I? I have been twice an under sheriff, man.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Canst thou empoison? canst thou empoison?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Excellently, no Jew, Apothecary, or Politician better look ye, here is a box, who wouldst thou empoison? here is a box which opened, and the fume taken up in conduits, through which the brain purges Itself , doth instantly for twelve hours space, bind up all show of life in a deep ceaseless sleep: here is another which being opened under the sleepers nose, chokes all the power of life, kills him suddenly.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I will try experiments, it is good not to be deceived: so, so, Catzo
Who would fear that may destroy, death hath no teeth, or tongue,
And he that is great, to him are slaves
Shame; Murder, fame and wrong.
Celzo?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My honoured Lord.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: The good Maleuole that plain tongued man, alas, is dead on sudden wondrous strangely, he held in our esteem good place. Celso see him buried, see him buried.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I shall observe ye.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: And Celso prithee let it be thy care tonight
To have some pretty show, to solemnise
Our high instalment, some music, masquery:
We will give fair entertain unto Maria
The Duchess to the banished Altofront
Thou shalt conduct her from the Citadel
Unto the Palace, think on some Masquery,

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Of what shape, sweet Lord?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Why shape? why any quick done fiction,
As some brave spirits of the Genoan Dukes,
To come out of Elizium forsooth,
Led in by Mercury to gratulate
sp.p: Our happy fortune, some such anything , some far set trick, good for Ladies, come stale toy or other, no matter soever be of our devising.
sp.l: Do thou prepare it , it is but for a fashion sake,
Fear not, it shall be graced man, it shall take.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: All service.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: All thanks, our hand shall not be close to thee farewell.
Now is my treachery secure, nor can we fall:
Mischief that prospers men do virtue call,
I will trust no man, he that by tricks gets wreathes,
Keeps them with steel, no man securely breathes,
Out of deserved ranks the crowd will mutter, fool:
Who cannot bear with spite, he cannot rule,
The chiefest secret for a man of state,
Is, to live senseless of a strengthless hate.
sp.p: Death of the damned thief: I will make one in the mask, thou shalt have some Brave spirits of the antique Dukes.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My Lord, what strange delusion?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Most happy, dear Celso poisoned with an empty box? I will give thee all anon: my Lady comes to court, there is a whirl of fate comes tumbling on, the Castles captain stands for me, the people pray for me, and the great leader of the just stands for me: then courage Celso
sp.l: For no disastrous chance can ever move him,
That leaveth nothing but a God above him.

body.stage: Enter Prepasso and Bilioso two pages before them Maquar: Beancha and Emilia

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Make room there room for the Ladies: why gentlemen, will not ye suffer the Ladies to be entered in the great chamber? why gallants? and you sir, to drop your Torch where the beauties must sit too.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: And there is a great fellow plays the knave, why dost not strike him?

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Let him play the knave a Gods name, thinkst thou I have no more wit then to strike a great fellow: the music, more lights, revelling, scaffolds: do you hear? let there be oaths enough ready at the door, swear out the devil himself. Let us leave the Ladies, and go see if the Lords be ready for them.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: And by my troth Beauties, why do you not put you into the fashion, this is a stale cut, you must come in fashion: look ye, you must be all felt, felt and feather, a felt upon your bare hair: look ye, these tiring things are justly out of request now: and do ye hear? you must were falling bands, you must come into the falling fashion: there is such a deal a pinning these ruffs, when the fine clean fall is worth all: and a gen, if you should chance to take a nap in the afternoon, your falling band requires no potting stick to recover his form: believe me, no fashion to the falling I say.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.l: And is not sinner Saint Andrew a gallant fellow now.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: By my maiden head la, honour and he agrees as well together as a satin suit and woollen stockings.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: But is not Marshall Make rome my servant in reversion a proper gentleman.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Yes in reversion as he had his office, as in truth he hath all things in reversion: he has his Mistress in reversion, his clothes in reversion, his wit in reversion: and indeed is a suitor to me, for my dog in reversion: but in good verity la, he is as proper a gentleman in reversion as: and indeed, as fine a man as may be, having a red beard and a pair of wrapped legs.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: But I saith I am most monstrously in love with count Quidlibet in Quodlibet, is he not a pretty dapper unidle gallant?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: He is even one of the most busy fingered Lords, he will put the beauties to the squeak most hideously.

sp.speaker: Bil:
sp.p: Room, make a lane there, the Duke is entering: stand handsomely for beauties sake, take up the Ladies there. So, cornets, cornets.

body.stage: Enter Prepasso ioynes to Bilioso two pages and lights, Ferrard, Mendozo at the other doore two pages with lights, and the Captaine leading in Maria the Duke meetes Maria and closeth with her, the rest fall backe.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Madam, with gentle ear receive my suit,
A kingdoms safety should over peise flight rites,
Marriage is merely Natures policy:
Then, since unless our royal beds be joined,
Danger and civil tumult frights the state.
Be wise as you are fair, give way to fate.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What wouldst thou, thou affliction to our house? Thou ever devil, it was thou that banishedest my truly noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: I?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Aye , by thy plots, by thy black stratagems,
Twelve Moons have suffered change since I beheld
The loved presence of my dearest Lord.
O thou far worse than death, he parts but soul
From a weak body: but thou, soul from soul
Disseverest, that which Gods own hand did knit.
Thou scant of honour, full of devilish wit.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: We will check your too intemperate lavishness
I can and will.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What canst?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Go to, in banishment thy husband dies.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He ever is at home that is ever wise,

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Youst never meet more, reason should love control,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not meet?
She that dear loves, her love is still in her soul.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: You are but a woman Lady, you must yield,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O save me thou innated bashfulness,
Thou only ornament of woman's modesty.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Modesty? Death I will torment thee,

sp.speaker: Mar,
sp.l: Do, urge all torments, all afflictions try,
I will die my Lords, as long as I can die,

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Thou obstinate, thou shalt die. Captain, that Ladies life is fortified to Justice, we have examined her,
sp.l: And we do find, she hath empoisoned
The reverend Hermit: therefore we command
Severest custody. Nay, if you will do us no good,
Youst do us no harm, a Tyrants peace is blood.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O thou art merciful, O gracious devil,
Rather by much let me condemned be
For seeming murder, than be damned for thee.
I will mourn no more, come girt my brows with flowers,
Revel and dance; soul, now thy wish thou hast,
Die like a Bride, poor heart thou shalt die chaste.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Life is a frost of could felicity,
And death the thaw of all our vanity,
Was it not an honest Priest that wrote so?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Who let her in?

sp.speaker: Bili.
sp.l: Forbear.

sp.speaker: Aur:
sp.l: Alas calamity, is everywhere .
Sad misery despite your double doors,
Will enter even in court.

sp.speaker: Bili.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I have done? one word, take heed, I have done.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Cillenian Mercury the God of ghosts,
From gloomy shades that spread the lower coasts,
Calls four high famed Genoan Dukes to come
And make this presence their Elizium
To pass away this high triumphal night,
With song and dances, courts more soft delight.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Are you God of ghosts, I have a suit depending in hell betwixt me and my conscience, I would fain have thee help me to an advocate.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.l: Mercury shall be your lawyer, Lady.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Nay faith, Mercury has too good a face, to be a right lawyer.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Peace, forbear: Mercury presents the mask.

body.stage: Cornets: The Song to the Cornets, which playing, the maske enters. Maleuole, Pietro, Ferneze and Celso in white robes, with Dukes Crownes vpon lawrell, wreathes, pistolets and short swords vnder their robes.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Celso, Celso count Maria for our love; Lady, be gracious, yet grace.

body.stage: Maleuole takes his wife to daunce.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: With me Sir?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Yes, more loved than my breath:
With you I will dance.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why then you dance with death,
But come Sir, I was never more apt to mirth.
Death gives eternity a glorious breath:
O, to die honoured, who would fear to die.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: They die in fear, who live in villainy.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: Yes believe him Lady, and be ruled by him.

body.stage: Pietro taks his wife Aurelia to dance.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.l: Madam, with me?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Wouldst then be miserable?

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.l: I need not wish.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O yet forbear my hand, away, fly, fly,
O seek not her, that only seeks to die.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.l: Poor loved soul.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: What, wouldst court misery?

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: She will come too soon, O my grieved heart

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.l: Lady, have done, have done.
Come, let us dance, be once from sorrow free.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: art a sad man.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.l: Yes sweet.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Then we will agree.

body.stage: Ferneze takes Maquerelle, and Celso Beancha: then the Cornets sound the measure, one change and rest.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Believe it Lady, shall I swear, let me enjoy you in private, and I will marry you by my soul.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: I had rather you would swear by your body: I think that would prove the more regarded oath with you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I will swear by them both, to please you.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.l: O, damn them not both to please me, for Gods sake.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Faith, sweet creature, let me enjoy you tonight , and I will marry you tomorrow fortnight, by my troth la.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: On his troth la, believe him not, that kind of cony catching is as stale as sir Oliuer Anchovies perfumed jerkin: promise of matrimony by a young gallant, to bring a virgin Lady into a fools paradise: make her a great woman, and then cast her off: it is as common as natural to a Courtier, as jealousy to a Citizen, gluttony to a Puritan, wisdom to an Alderman, pride to a Tailor, or an empty handbasket to one of these sixpenny damnations: of his troth la, believe him not, traps to catch polecats.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Keep your face constant, let no sudden passion speak in your eyes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O my Altofront

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.l: A tyrants jealousies
are very nimble, you receive it all.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: My heart, though not my knees, doth visibly fall,
Low as the earth to thee.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.l: Peace, next change, no words.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Speech to such, aye, O what will affords?

body.stage: Cornets sound the measure ouer againe: which danced they vnmaske.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Meleauole?

body.stage: They environ Mendozo bending their Pistolles on him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Altofront, Duke Pietro, Ferneze ha?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Duke Altofront, Duke Altofront

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Are we surprised? what strange delusions mock
Our senses, do I dream? or have I dreamt.
This two days space? where am I?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Where an arch villain is.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: O lend me breath, till I am fit to die.
For peace with heaven, for your own souls sake,
Vouchsafe me life.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Ignoble villain, whom neither heaven nor hell, goodness of God or man, could once make good.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Base treacherous wretch, what grace canst thou expect
That had grown impudent in gracelessness.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: O life

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Slave, take thy life.
Wert thou defenced through blood and wounds,
The sternest horror of a civil fight.
Would I achieve thee: but prostrate at my feet
I scorn to hurt thee: It is the heart of slaves
That deigns to triumph over peasants graves.
For such thou art, since birth doth near enrol
A man among monarchs, but a glorious soul.
You are joyed spirits wipe your long wet eyes,
Hence with this man: an Eagle takes not flies.
You to your vows:
And thou unto the suburbs.
You to my worst friend I would hardly give:
Thou art a perfect old knave, all pleased live.
You two unto my breast:
Thou to my heart.
The rest of idle actors idly part,
And as for me I here assume my right,
To which I hope all is pleased: to all goodnight.
